titlestmt.titleproper: Park West Village Tenants Association Records TAM.333
titlestmt.author: Finding aid prepared by Tamiment staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using the Archivists' Toolkit 2014-12-01T16:03-0500

change.item: Edited by Heather Mulliner to reflect updated administrative information

did.unittitle: Park West Village Tenants Association Records

repository.corpname: Tamiment Library and Robert F. Wagner Labor Archive

did.abstract: The Park West Village Tenants Association represents the tenants of seven apartment buildings on New York City's Upper West Side (372, 382, 392, 400 Central Park West, and 784, 788, 792 Colmbus Avenue), built with with Federal subsidy in the late 1950s. The four Central Park West buildings have become condominiums. The Association seeks to preserve the rent stabilized, middle income status of the three remaining rental buildings, to ensure the proper maintenance of the property, and protect the rights of individual tenants of the buildings, and the tenants as a whole. The collection contains legal materials, government documents, minutes, reports, correspondence, newsletters, subject files, printed ephemera, and clippings. NOTE: This collection is housed offsite and advance notice is required for use.
did.physloc: Materials are stored offsite and advance notice is required for use. Please contact tamiment.wagner@library.nyu.edu at least two business days prior to research visit.

origination.label: creator
origination.corpname: Park West Village Tenants Association (New York, N.Y.).

bioghist.head: Historical/Biographical Note
bioghist.p: The Park West Village Tenants Association represents the tenants of seven apartment buildings on New York City's Upper West Side (372, 382, 392, 400 Central Park West, and 784, 788, 792 Colmbus Avenue), built with with Federal subsidy in the late 1950s. The four Central Park West buildings have become condominiums. The Association seeks to preserve the rent stabilized, middle income status of the three remaining rental buildings, to ensure the proper maintenance of the property, and protect the rights of individual tenants of the buildings, and the tenants as a whole.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The collection contains legal materials, government documents, minutes, reports, correspondence, newsletters, subject files, printed ephemera, and clippings. See the container list, below, for a brief description of the contents of each box of this unprocessed collection. NOTE: This collection is housed offsite and advance notice is required for use.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Identification of item, date; Park West Village Tenants Association Records; TAM 333; box number; folder number; Tamiment Library/Robert F. Wagner Labor Archives, New York University.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: Any rights (including copyright and related rights to publicity and privacy) held by the Park West Village Tenants Association, the creator of this collection, were transferred to New York University in 2004. Permission to publish or reproduce materials in this collection must be secured from the Tamiment Library.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition note
acqinfo.p: Albina DeMeio and Winifred Armstrong on behalf of the Park West Village Tenants Association sent nine boxes of the Park West Village Tenants Association records in 2004. The accession number associated with this gift is 2004.034. The Park West Village Tenants Association sent an additional eleven boxes of their records in 2010. The accession number associated with this gift is 2010.017

processinfo.head: Processing Information note
processinfo.p: In 2014, the archived website was added as a series.

did.unittitle: Contents: Letters dated July 13 and August 11, 1993 concerning a roadway to be constructed on the property including buildings 372, 382, 392 and 400 CPW; A renters guide prepared by PWVTA in September 1992; Copies of covenants concerning the building of Park West Village; The Black Book and other papers pertaining to the Condominium Offering Plan for 392 CPW; The detailed history of the rent reduction and MCI battle between the tenants of 784, 788 and 792 Columbus Ave which began in 1993 and was finally settled in 2005.

Contents: Executive Board minutes and agendas 1991-1992; Legal material re: Balconies in 400 CPW; Fences Fight in CPW buildings in the early 1990s; PWVTA Membership lists 1993-1995, all seven buildings, and letters re conversion; CPW 400 Awning 1995; Early conversion material: brad brewwer argument, survey 5/28/1984, Court Case 372/382; Newsletters 1982-1988; Election 1991; Harassment casev (ambriose) 400 CPW; Roy Harris eviction case, mostly from 792 and 400 in 2000.
Contents: Red Tailed Hawk 1994-1996; Fence issue, CPW buildings; Newsletters - assorted files for 372 CPW and other issues in the 1990s
Contents: Fliers and newswletters; Some board meeting notes and agendas (Note: many duplicates)
Contents: General - mainly 372 Central Park West

Contents: Intercom Files -784, 788, 792 Columbus Ave; Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR) Rent Reduction Petitions, Complaints, Legal Documents; Tenant Window Depositions; Newsletters, Fliers
Contents: Division of Housing and Community Renewal (DHCR)Legal Documents: Complaints, PAR Exhibits, Security Remands re 784, 788, 792 Columbus Ave; Robert J. Anderson's Comments
Contents: Legal materials: Security Reduction; Window MCI's
Contents: Legal materials: Screening Rent Reductions, Window MCI at 792 Columbus Ave
Contents: Bess Mitchell Files, including Harrassment Case, Board Meetings, mostly from 400 CPW
Contents: Conversion of 392/400 CPW - including correspondence with Attorney General's Office 1989-1992; Vivian Dee Files (President) 2000-2002

Contents: Vivian Dee Files (President) 2000-2002; Overcharge Cases /Division of Housing and Community Renewal Settlement from 784-788-792 Columbus Ave (Florence Wagener Files): Aptaker, Lisa; Anderson, Linda; Anthony, Peter; Fackler, Peter H. 2000-2004

Contents: Overcharge Cases from 784-788-792 Columbus Ave (Florence Wagener Files)/ Division of Housing and Community Renewal Settlement : Feldman, Jason; Fleck, Richard; Kantor, Molly; Glowski, Matt; Lammers, Brent; Nack, Jessica; Nakaniski, Yuki; Pace, William; Purdy, Colin; Rose, Lisa; Resnick, Adam; Santora, Frank; Sorotzkin, Steven; Stepanchek, Tom; Squillacioti, Kathleen; Velyvis, Peter; Williamson, John; Zuckerman, John; Wangh, Anne

Contents: Consolidated DHCR Overcharge Cases (Note: DHCR Final Order is confidential - owner payments may not be quoted but Rent Rollback can be) 2002-2005; Dan Dunbar Files: administrative documents, newsletters, etc. 1997-2007

Contents: Dan Dunbar Files: administrative documents, newsletters, etc. 1996-2007; 400 Central Park West Black Book and 792 Complaint Forms; Legal Files - mainly from Dean Hefner: File 1. Diminution of Services, Comp Agreement drafts, Rent Strike, File 2. MCI 1992-2002, File 3. DHCR Consolidated Overcharge Case 2005; 400 Central Park West Roof Repair and Rent Decrease Case from Winifred Armstrong 1988

Contents: Legal Files: Early and Current Cases: File 4. Property Agreements, 1950s, Certificates of Occupancy of 784, 788, 792, including parking; Harrassment Case 1987, Challenge to Condo Case 1984, Hardship Case 1979; File 5 Injuction 2006; File 6 MCI 2004-2006; Legal Files from Sylvia Friedrich
Contents: Parking Case - DHCR Decision
Contents: Administrative documents, fliers, correspondence; Winifred Armstrong Files (Editor of PWVTA Newsletter); Vicki Lawrence Papers, includes Condo Case 1984

Contents: Proposed road thru PWV at 99th St., 1993; Disputed Fence & Awning, 1993; Land Use, 2005-6; Proposed welcome pamphlet, 1996; Playground, 1988-2001; Apartment registrations, 2003; Rent overcharge, 2001-2004; Hardship case, 1978
Archived Website

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: Park West Village Tenants’ Association, first active in 1974, is a voluntary, non-profit, membership organization whose purposes are to protect the rights and welfare of tenants in Park West Village (PWV); keep PWV tenants informed of their rights; represent PWVTA members in negotiations with Park West managements; represent the concerns of PWVTA members to outside organizations and to elected officials and government agencies; and support and participate in campaigns by various organizations; to expand tenant rights; strengthen rent regulations; preserve affordable housing programs; and protect the ability of low-income and moderate-income tenants to remain in their homes. They are affiliated with Tenants and Neighbors and the Metropolitan Council on Housing. The website contains resources, a renters’ guide, photos, and history.
